The Inverse Exponential distribution

Source: R/dist_inverse_exponential.R
dist_inverse_exponential.Rd

dist_inverse_exponential(rate)

Arguments

rate

an alternative way to specify the scale.

See also

actuar::InverseExponential

Examples

dist <- dist_inverse_exponential(rate = 1:5)
dist
#> <distribution[5]>
#> [1] InvExp(1) InvExp(2) InvExp(3) InvExp(4) InvExp(5)

mean(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
variance(dist)
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA
support(dist)
#> <support_region[5]>
#> [1] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf]
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1] 4.9050894 2.0589099 1.2913684 1.3075583 0.8440164 2.0087602 4.3099979
#>  [8] 2.7374080 1.5069604 0.4428906
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1]  0.6187422  1.3848287  0.2351509  0.6672013  0.7513579  0.5686139
#>  [7]  0.3145525  0.8585371  0.3685672 10.0038303
#> 
#> [[3]]
#>  [1]   0.2727242   1.2309635   0.5908202   3.9840742   1.2911578   1.2900372
#>  [7]   0.2146211  25.9939213 216.2060622   0.3137158
#> 
#> [[4]]
#>  [1] 0.2304026 9.0683635 0.5515137 0.8307221 0.4181040 0.7352612 0.1200830
#>  [8] 0.4059432 0.2412584 0.1476377
#> 
#> [[5]]
#>  [1] 0.98174620 0.50036910 0.08160981 1.32139139 0.17111703 0.37576776
#>  [7] 0.15086821 0.06522254 0.68913916 0.48105251
#> 

density(dist, 2)
#> [1] 0.15163266 0.09735010 0.07054014 0.05515606 0.04524187
density(dist, 2, log = TRUE)
#> [1] -1.886294 -2.329442 -2.651573 -2.897589 -3.095732

cdf(dist, 4)
#> [1] 0.7788008 0.8824969 0.9200444 0.9394131 0.9512294

quantile(dist, 0.7)
#> [1] 2.8036733 1.4018366 0.9345578 0.7009183 0.5607347
